#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|

#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Researchquestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Timeperiodofstudy|
#Text=Multiyear trajectories of stream and riparian responses to beaver dam analogs on a low_gradient channel lacking woody riparian vegetation.

#Text=Matthew R Orr,�Nicholas P Weber,�Ron J Reuter,�Skuyler P Herzog,�Heather M Broughton,�Samantha Bango\rFirst published: 15 July 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14223\rAuthor contributions: MRO, NPW, RR, SPH, HMB conceived and designed the research; MRO, NPW, RR, SPH, SB conducted fieldwork; MRO, NPW, RR, SPH, HMB, SB analyzed data; MRO, NPW, RR, SPH, HMB wrote the manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Margaret Palmer\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Beaver_based restoration techniques seek to assist with the recovery of stream systems that have been damaged, degraded, or destroyed.
#Text=In addition to reintroducing beaver, restoration practitioners have sought to mimic the influence of beaver dams on stream processes by building beaver dam analogs (BDAs).
#Text=Stream restoration has been criticized for a lack of extended monitoring and a dearth of empirical evidence for the efficacy of BDAs.
#Text=Here, we extend early and previously reported 1_ to 2_year monitoring of five BDAs on a low_gradient stream lacking woody riparian vegetation to 3_6years, depending on the parameter examined.
#Text=BDAs raised groundwater near the stream and did not affect water temperatures during the duration of monitoring.

#Text=Consistent with elevated groundwater levels, riparian willow cuttings grew 2.8_9.6 times more when planted near BDAs than far from BDAs, which was more than the 1.3_ to 1.4_fold difference after the first growing season.
#Text=In contrast, a short_term association between BDAs and willow survival disappeared in the long term.

#Text=Likewise, sediment aggradation above the upstream BDA 1year after construction reversed completely 4years later, probably due to structural damage during high flows that could not be repaired until flows abated.
#Text=Annual peak flow levels explained over 80% of the variation in the number of structures requiring annual repair.

#Text=Our results suggest that BDA_based restoration should account for both the costs of structure maintenance during project planning and the importance of long_term monitoring during project assessment.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Peak flows degrade the structural integrity of beaver dam analogs (BDAs) and increase the effort required to maintain them, making hydrographs an important planning tool in BDA_based restoration.\r* Maintaining the structural integrity of BDAs supports some restoration responses, such as groundwater and vegetation, better than others, such as sediment retention, which means maintenance should be contextualized to specific project goals.\r* Short_term restoration responses to BDAs do not necessarily predict long_term responses, making long_term monitoring necessary to fully appraise restoration success.
#Text=Introduction.
#Text=Ecological restoration targets ecosystem structure to improve ecosystem function (Bradshaw�1996; Rey Benayas et al�2009).

#Text=Species composition is a primary component of ecosystem structure (SER International Science & Policy Working Group�2004), and organisms having a high community impact, such as keystone species or ecosystem engineers, may exert profound restoration effects (Byers et al�2006; Hale & Koprowski�2018).
#Text=As ecosystem engineers, beavers transport wood from terrestrial to aquatic systems, affecting geomorphology, flows, water quality, and freshwater ecology (Brazier et al�2021).

#Text=Trapping and extirpation of beavers across North America during the nineteenth century (eg Ott�2003) contributed to the degradation of North American streams (Butler & Malanson�2005; Pollock et al�2007; Fouty�2018).
#Text=Practitioners have reintroduced beavers to locations of historic decline in efforts to restore historic conditions (Castro et al�2023).
#Text=Restorationists have sought to support or bypass beaver reintroductions by building structures that mimic their engineering effects (Norman et al�2022).
#Text=Structures that mimic natural beaver dams are known as beaver dam analogs (BDAs, Pollock et al�2014).

#Text=BDAs are one method employed to achieve process_based restoration, which endeavors to support streambed aggradation, floodplain connectivity, groundwater recharge, and the growth of riparian woody vegetation on the many miles of wadable waterways where construction of such structures is feasible (Wheaton et al�2019).

#Text=Process_based protocols (eg Wheaton & MacFarlane�2014; Wheaton et al�2019; Castro et al�2023) have been widely implemented (eg Simmons & Vanderwal�2018; Smith�2023) and have made BDAs one of the fastest_growing approaches to stream restoration in the western United States (Goldfarb�2018).

#Text=As is true of ecological restoration in general (Lindenmayer�2020), both stream restoration (Kondolf & Micheli�1995) and BDA_based restoration (Lautz et al�2019) have been criticized for lacking breadth and duration of monitoring.

#Text=Of the 21 structure_based projects listed in a 2017 review of beaver_based restoration, only five were published (table S3 in Pilliod et al�2018), and only two of the five met criteria for process_based restoration (Gard�1961; Bouwes et al�2016).
#Text=Of the 16 remaining unpublished projects, 5 listed no monitoring dates and 11 had a median of just 1year of monitoring (Pilliod et al�2018).

#Text=In addition, none of three BDA_based restoration projects described in�The Beaver Restoration Guidebook�(Castro et al�2015, Chapter 11, project numbers 5, 7, and 9) provided monitoring data beyond short_term photos or qualitative descriptions, and none were updated in subsequent editions of the guide (Castro et al�2017,�2023).
#Text=To date, BDA monitoring remains limited (Table�1) (note that Table�1�does not address BDA effects on vertical hydraulic gradients, which are summarized elsewhere; Cero et al�2023).
#Text=Table 1.
#Text=�Published reports of stream and riparian parameters monitored after the installation of beaver dam analogs (BDAs).

#Text=In column 1, two numbers (N/N) are given if a subset (N) of all structures (N) was monitored, and an asterisk indicates that at least some structures were reported or inferred from figures to be less than 10m apart, which is a rule of thumb for a dam complex (Hafen et al�2020).
#Text=Columns 2__6 show the number of years each parameter was monitored.
#Text=The desired direction of a parameter for supporting a restoration outcome is listed in each column heading beside each parameter.
#Text=Symbols in rows indicate whether a parameter increased (+), decreased (), did not change (�), or was inconclusive ().
#Text=Water temperatures are daily maxima in the summer months.

#Text=In the vegetation column, the method of monitoring normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI); enhanced vegetation index (EVI) and whether vegetation already existed or was added during restoration are noted.

#Text=Site (Nstructures)\rStructure integrity �, +\rPlanform/sediment +\rWater temperature �, \rGroundwater +\rVegetation +\rCitation(s)\rBridge Creek, Oregon (>100*)\r4 ()\r4 (+, )\r4 (�, )\r4 (+)\r7 (+) NDVI, existing\rBouwes et al (2016)\rWeber et al (2017)\rSilverman et al (2019)\rMissouri Headwaters Basin, Montana (34)\r\r\r\r\r1__3 (�, +) NDVI, existing\rVanderhoof and Burt (2018)\rBlacktail drainage, Montana (63*)\r\r\r\r1__3 (+)\r\rNorman (2020)\rSouth Fork Crooked River, Oregon (5)\r2 ()\r1 (+, , �)\r2 (�)\r2 (+)\r0.3 (+) growth added\rOrr et al (2019)\rFish & Campbell Creeks, Colorado (8/16)\r\r1 (+)\r\r1 (�)\r\rScamardo and Wohl (2020)\rRed Canyon Creek, Wyoming (5)\r1 ()\r1 (+, )\r1 (�)\r1 (+)\r\rPearce et al�(2021a,�2021b)\rRed Canyon Creek, Wyoming (3)\r5 ()\r3 ()\r\r\r\rDavis et al (2021)\rPine Creek (14*)\r\r\r3 (+, )\r3 (+)\r\rMunir and Westbrook�(2021a,�2021b)\rBlacktail Creek, Montana (10)\r\r\r\r\r5 (�) EVI, existing\rAskam et al (2022)\rSalt Lake Catchment (>70)\r3 ()\r\r\r\r\rWolf and Hammill (2023)\rFrench Creek, California (4)\r\r\r2 ()\r\r\rCorline et al (2023)\rScott River, California (4)\r1 ()\r\r\r\r\rYokel et al (2023)\rScott River tributaries, California (20*)\r1__8 ()\r\r3__5 ()\r\r\rYokel et al (2023)\rCalls for further monitoring identify a need to understand how BDAs function across a range of stream and riparian conditions (Bouwes et al�2016; Lautz et al�2019; Nash et al�2021).
#Text=This study monitors a set of BDAs installed on a low_gradient stream lacking woody riparian vegetation.

#Text=A low gradient may reduce stream power, which could enhance structure longevity and thus promote long_term restoration outcomes such as elevating groundwater to support riparian woody vegetation.
#Text=However, a low gradient may also mobilize sediments poorly, causing aggradation to occur too slowly to reconnect treated reaches to their floodplain.

#Text=This potential tradeoff between sediment transport and structure longevity is a key consideration in the process pathways and contingencies that affect the success of beaver_based restoration (Nash et al�2021, pp 258__259).

#Text=To determine whether beaver_based interventions achieve restoration goals, other processes merit monitoring, including whether dams cause groundwater levels to rise and whether rising groundwater supports vegetation growth (Nash et al�2021).

#Text=BDAs have been shown to support the growth and spread of preexisting vegetation, but their ability to support riparian reforestation in areas devoid of woody species is mostly unknown (Table�1).

#Text=Initial monitoring of the project we report here documented inconsistent sediment dynamics behind different BDAs, high aggradation at the upstream structure, stable stream temperatures, elevated groundwater, and a small early growth and survival advantage to willow cuttings planted in the vicinity of BDAs (Orr et al�2019).

#Text=Most of these parameters were monitored over a few months to 2years, which, although not inconsistent with the monitoring periods of other BDA projects (Table�1; table S3 in Pilliod et al�2018), nevertheless merits further study to understand whether initial results predict long_term trajectories (Pollock et al�2014; Wheaton et al�2019).

#Text=In this study, we asked the following questions concerning BDA performance over a 4_ to 6_year period after installation on a low_gradient stream lacking woody riparian vegetation: (1) Do early trajectories in_stream and riparian parameters hold over the longer term This question is important because short_term monitoring cannot capture infrequent events and interannual contingencies, such as flooding, that are known to influence beaver_based restoration (Nash et al�2021), and thus may alter the trajectory of BDA impacts. (2) What are the relationships between stream flows, BDA water retention, and groundwater profiles This question was addressed with monthly monitoring over two summers in our prior work.

#Text=Here, we address it with continuous monitoring over an additional 2years, which will help to assess how consistently BDAs support woody vegetation and whether in our system they may store groundwater for recharge during low flows. (3) How much maintenance is needed to maintain the structural integrity of BDAs, and is it affected by peak stream flows This question is important given the limited budgets for restoration, especially in basins with flashy hydrographs and in projects where structures must remain intact over multiple years to achieve restoration outcomes.

#Text=All three of these questions address intra_ and/or interannual contingencies that have been identified as key issues in beaver_based restoration (Nash et al�2021) and which could make it difficult to extrapolate short_term responses to BDAs to longer time scales.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Study Area.
#Text=Our study area on the South Fork of the Crooked River, including BDA structure construction and images, is described in Orr et al (2019) and summarized in Figure�1.
#Text=The South Fork is almost entirely devoid of naturally occurring woody riparian vegetation, despite evidence indicating its past presence (Fig�2).

#Text=It has a mostly single_thread planform and a gradient ranging from 0.1 to 0.4%, which is approximately an order of magnitude less than the 1__3% gradient on Bridge Creek, where BDAs have been shown to capture sediment and stimulate the growth of preexisting woody riparian vegetation (Bouwes et al�2016).
#Text=The South Fork is spring_fed and experiences its highest flows during snow melt, with annual peaks that may vary by approximately an order of magnitude (>300 to 40cfs) between years.
#Text=Low flows occur mid_summer and can be exacerbated by upstream water withdrawals for flood irrigation (Fig�3).
#Text=Our site is in United States Department of Agriculture plant hardiness zone 6a (planthardiness.ars.usda.gov/) and has a 90__120days growing season.

#Text=To extend prior monitoring, which was conducted from the time of BDA construction in July 2016 until fall 2018 (Orr et al�2019), we maintained structures yearly from spring 2019 through fall 2022, and extended monitoring of sedimentation from 1 to 5years, monitoring of temperatures from 2 to 4years, and monitoring of willow growth from one growing season to four, while roughly doubling the number of plants monitored.
#Text=Figure 1\r\rStudy layout.
#Text=The inset (red star) shows the approximate location in Oregon.
#Text=Yellow circles mark the stream distance from the upper end of the study site.
#Text=Orange triangles show beaver dam analogs (BDAs), which were first installed in July 2016.
#Text=Red pins show thermometer locations.
#Text=Green symbols are willow copses for the 2019 cohort (2018 is almost the same as shown in Orr et al�2019).
#Text=White polygons are sedimentation areas of interest (AOIs); AOI 1 encompasses BDA 1 and AOI 2 encompasses BDAs 3__5.
#Text=Figure 2\r\rStudy site conditions.
#Text=(A) 1920s photo shows a tall stand of woody riparian vegetation (arrow) within our study reach almost a half_century after grazing commenced; such stands are nonexistent today.
#Text=(B) Riparian willow (circled) upstream from our study reach (lat 44 degrees 0206, long __120 degrees 0135).
#Text=(C) Volunteer willow at our site survive beaver herbivory only if fenced.

#Text=(D) A nearby Crooked River tributary, Newsome Creek (lat 44 degrees 0756, long __120 degrees 2837), 23 mi west of our study site, where riparian woody vegetation is dense and beaver activity is high on the south property (white fenceline) but absent on a neighboring property north of the road, where cattle have unlimited access to the stream.
#Text=(E) A beaver lodge at our study site was built from upland woody vegetation (sage and bitterbrush).
#Text=(F) After the landowner at our site installed a log across the stream to try to raise water levels, beaver attempted to augment it with upland shrubs (circle).
#Text=Figure 3\r\rStream flows at our study site on the South Fork (blue, left�y_axis) and on the mainstem Crooked (orange, right�y_axis) from January 2016 through June 2023.

#Text=�n�is the number of structures requiring repair, followed by the number of person_hours spent on repair, which included neither transportation to the site nor procurement and sharpening of added posts.
#Text=Note that periods of structure failure followed years of high flows.
#Text=In 2023, n/a signifies that structures were no longer being maintained, so no hours were invested in repair even though it was needed.
#Text=Structure Integrity and Water Levels\rTo assess the general integrity of BDAs, structures were checked once each in the spring or early summer, and fall.

#Text=They were maintained during periods of easy wading when they were not holding water to their full height, which happened as vegetation in structures lost foliage or, more notably, when high flows dislodged dam materials or created gaps in the substrate around or under structures.
#Text=To repair structures, we wove new woody vegetation into the gaps and added soft riparian vegetation, gravel, or rocks to the upstream side of the BDA.
#Text=To repair under_scour and end cuts, we drove new posts to replace loose or missing posts and added woody vegetation, soft vegetation, rocks, and gravel where needed.

#Text=We kept a log of structures requiring attention and person_hours spent on maintenance, which we deemed complete when the repaired area had equal integrity to the remaining structure and water levels returned across the top of the BDA.

#Text=In the fall of 2020, after all summer BDA repairs were complete, we added post_assisted log structures (PALs) (Wheaton et al�2019, Chapter 4) approximately 2__3m downstream of BDAs 1, 2, and 5 to within 1m of a channel_spanning width.
#Text=This was done to further support structures, and the time spent building them was not logged as maintenance.

#Text=To test for relationships between peak flow levels and BDA maintenance requirements, we used gage data from the Oregon Water Resources Department Near Real Time Hydrographics Data website (apps.wrd.state.or.us/apps/sw/hydro_near_real_time/).

#Text=The stream gage on the South Fork, 14km upstream of our study site, was decommissioned in 2019 in the middle of our study, so we employed the gage on the mainstem Crooked River above Prineville Reservoir, 75km downstream of our site, as a proxy measure for South Fork flows.

#Text=To assess the reliability of the proxy, we measured the correlation between daily stream flows on the South Fork and mainstem Crooked gages over the lifespan of the South Fork gage (1 October 2014 to 20 July 2019).
#Text=We regarded the peak flow as the highest flow recorded that year.

#Text=The relationship between peak flow and the number of structures requiring annual maintenance was tested using linear regression in SPSS after log_transforming flow rates and hours spent on labor to fit assumptions of linearity.

#Text=We also analyzed the time required for maintenance in two ways: first, using actual maintenance times, and second, using the same times but adding an estimate for the last year of study, when we assessed structure damage but did not conduct maintenance.
#Text=The estimate was made based on the levels of damage in the final year and our past experience of the time it took to conduct similar repairs in previous years.

#Text=To monitor the level and consistency of support that BDAs offered to riparian plantings over periods of potential summer water stress, we deployed in_stream stilling wells 1__2m upstream and downstream of BDAs at two locations (BDA 5 in 2020 and 2021 and BDA 3 in 2021; Fig�1), accompanied by groundwater wells placed 2, 7, and 12m into the bank and perpendicular to flow on the river left immediately above each BDA and adjacent to willow cuttings.

#Text=We also monitored control wells situated 2m into the bank at both the downstream and upstream ends of our study reach (Fig�1) to assess fluctuations in water levels coming into and going out of our system.
#Text=For a short time, we also inserted an in_stream control well adjacent to the upstream bank control to track the connectivity of surface and streambank water levels at that location.
#Text=Wells were identical to those described in Orr et al (2019).

#Text=They were built by a professional well driller and consisted of a 1.5m long, 3.8cm diameter steel pipe slitted on three sides to within 10cm of the bottom and 60cm of the top, with the inserted end cut and welded into a closed point, and a cap (Oatey model 33400 1.5 in) fitted to the top.
#Text=Slits were always below the ground surface.

#Text=We inserted HOBO U20L water level loggers (Onset, Bourne, MA, U.S.A.) into each well and in shaded tree canopies to correct for fluctuations in ambient air pressure according to standard protocols (eg Puttock et al�2017; Wohl et al�2022).
#Text=All loggers were set to record at 15_minute intervals.

#Text=In total, six wells were monitored in 2020 at BDA 5 (in the river above and below the BDA, three in the bank, downstream control), with seven wells added in 2021 (five at BDA 3, plus two upstream controls).
#Text=In both 2020 and 2021, we noted that water levels were lower inside vs. immediately outside of the in_stream well upstream from BDA 5.

#Text=The discrepancy at BDA 5 was likely due to a combination of a steep hydraulic gradient at the BDA and clogging of the stilling well perforations by debris, sediment, and siltation within the well up to the level of the logger in 2021.

#Text=We corrected these portions of the water level time series by adding field_measured depth offsets (ie 0.27m for 18 July 2020__17 October 2020, 0.29m for all of 2021 monitoring) and by correlation to the BDA 3 upstream stilling well in 2021, which yielded approximate agreement with field observations and other well data.
#Text=In wells other than the one upstream of BDA 5, our field checks found equal heights of stilling wells and the surrounding surface water.
#Text=Sedimentation\rDetailed surveys of channel topography were conducted to further document the dynamics and magnitude of sediment erosion and deposition around BDA structures.
#Text=Topographic surveys were conducted throughout two areas of interest (AOI) that encompassed the installation locations of BDA structures (Fig�1).
#Text=AOIs had lengths of 80 and 157m, channel gradients of 0.58 and 0.21%, and contained either one or three BDA structures within AOIs 1 and 2, respectively.
#Text=Topographic surveys were conducted on three occasions to quantify sediment dynamics around BDA structures at short (months) and long (years) periods after construction.
#Text=Two of the three surveys were reported by Orr et al (2019): the summer of 2016 before BDAs were installed and fall of 2017, which followed the first year of high flows.
#Text=Here, we report an additional survey conducted in the fall of 2021, approximately 4years after BDA construction.
#Text=On each occasion, topographic surveys were conducted using a real_time kinematic�GPS or a survey_grade total station.
#Text=Repeat surveys used permanently monumented controls and adhered to a threshold of horizontal and vertical accuracy of less than 3cm.

#Text=The surveys captured a high density of spatially referenced points and break lines at a distribution sufficient to represent the channel, banks, and surrounding floodplain and terrace topography (Bouwes et al�2011).
#Text=Raw survey data was post_processed in a global information system�to construct 0.1m digital elevation models (DEM) of channel surface topography for each period (ie 2016, 2017, or 2021).
#Text=The DEMs were then differenced using the Geomorphic Change Detection software (Bailey et al�2020) to quantify changes in channel and bank elevation due to sediment erosion and deposition.

#Text=Only elevation changes greater than 0.1m were used to calculate volumes of sediment erosion and deposition to avoid including perceived elevation changes that may be due to bed substrate inconsistencies.
#Text=Volumes of sediment erosion/deposition were quantified for the initial response to BDA implementation (2016__2017) and the subsequent long_term response (2017__2021).

#Text=The analyses were constrained to include only areas of the channel and banks that would have been influenced by flow events occurring during the study period (ie high terraces away from the active channel and floodplain were not included in elevation change analyses).

#Text=Separate sediment change analyses were also evaluated for process zones in the immediate vicinity of BDA structures that corresponded with areas in the channel just upstream and downstream of BDA structures and at bank end cuts that occurred during the first high_flow periods following implementation in 2016 (Fig�5A__C).
#Text=Stream Temperatures.
#Text=Stream temperatures were measured upstream and downstream of BDA complexes to capture potential influences of solar heating in ponded water behind BDAs.
#Text=Temperature was also recorded at the entrance and exit of the stream study reach at river kilometer (RKM) 0 and RKM 3.5 (Fig�1).
#Text=Additionally, topographic maps and our on_site observations suggested potential groundwater inputs from springs and seeps, so temperature was measured upstream and downstream of these features.
#Text=Stream temperature was recorded with Onset HOBO Tidbit data loggers (accuracy +/_0.2 degrees C).
#Text=Loggers were attached to rebar posts inserted into the thalweg approximately 20cm above the substrate.
#Text=Temperature was logged hourly.
#Text=Loggers were deployed from July to October 2020 and June to October 2021, capturing two seasons of temperatures.
#Text=Due to high winter flows, loggers could not remain in place year_round.
#Text=Before deployment and after retrieval, loggers underwent quality assurance and control (QA/QC) testing with a lab_certified thermometer (Heck et al�2018).
#Text=Acceptable loggers were within +/_0.5 degrees C of the certified thermometer.
#Text=All retrieved loggers passed the QA/QC requirements.
#Text=Mean daily maximum temperatures were compared between various paired locations (eg upstream and downstream of a BDA) using a paired two_sample�t�test (two_tailed).
#Text=Well loggers deployed in the groundwater wells, described above, recorded the groundwater temperature.
#Text=Groundwater well loggers were not QA/QC tested and had a manufacturer_assigned accuracy of +/_0.4 degrees C.
#Text=Riparian Vegetation.
#Text=We monitored two cohorts of Coyote willow (Salix exigua) cuttings planted adjacent to reaches with or without BDAs (Fig�1).
#Text=Cohort 1 was planted on 4_5 May 2018.
#Text=Its planting methodology and first summer of growth were reported by Orr et al (2019).

#Text=Cohort 2 was planted on 3__5 May 2019, using the same methods and adjacent to most of the same locations along the stream as cohort 1 (Fig�1; compare with fig 1 in Orr et al�2019), except in 2019 we used a metal bar and manual post pounder to prepare holes in every instance.
#Text=All cohort 2 plants were planted to identical depths of 61cm, then cut to an aboveground height of 91cm.
#Text=(This depth was 6cm deeper than the mean planting depth of cohort 1 plants [53.4+/_27cm].)
#Text=We had sought to plant all cuttings to 90cm (Hoag�2007), but could not achieve those depths at most sites due to impenetrable substrate.

#Text=Stem diameters of cohort 2 were 1.26+/_0.29cm, which left roughly half of the plants below the recommended minimum diameter of 1.27cm (Logar & Scianna�2005), which was unavoidable based on availability at harvest.
#Text=All cuttings were enclosed in galvanized, 1.82_m high welded wire fencing.

#Text=We did not see signs of ungulate or beaver forage on any plants within our cages, but herbivory of uncaged plants at this site is common, and we have found uncaged willow cuttings planted for past restoration projects uprooted and stored inside beaver bank dens.
#Text=The 2019 cohort 2 planting design differed slightly from cohort 1.

#Text=Cohort 2 cuttings were planted in copses of 10 cuttings per copse, two copses (one near [0.5_3m] and one far [9_16m] from the stream) per location, over eight locations (four adjacent to a BDA and four far from a BDA; Fig�1).
#Text=Copses were on level ground.
#Text=Distances from the stream were chosen to make their elevation relative to the water surface as uniform as possible based on local topography.
#Text=The center elevation of each copse relative to adjacent stream surface water was measured using a rod and transit, with near copses 25__49.5cm and far copses 48.5__64.5cm above surface water.

#Text=All elevations above surface water were measured the same day and relative to the water level immediately below BDAs at locations where BDAs were present, which meant copses adjacent to BDAs experienced a rise in groundwater commensurate with the additional groundwater retained by each structure.

#Text=We monitored plant growth as in Orr et al (2019) by totaling the length of all live stems on a plant, except in the last year of measurement, 2022, when enough growth had occurred to make it impractical to measure stems shorter than 20cm, which were excluded from measurement.
#Text=Each cohort was measured after its first summer (4months) of growth, then 1 and 4years after planting for cohort 1 and 3years after planting for cohort 2.

#Text=Willow Growth and Survival Statistics\rFor each year of growth measurements, plants without live growth were re_coded as dead and used only for a survival analysis, while plants exhibiting live growth were coded as alive and used in a growth analysis.
#Text=Growth was analyzed for normality using a Shapiro__Wilk test (Royston�1995).
#Text=As growth data were non_normal, growth analyses were conducted using Gaussian generalized linear mixed models (GLMMs) with a log link (Bolker et al�2009).
#Text=GLMMs for growth included GROWTH as the dependent variable, a fixed effect for SITE, and independent variables for the nearby presence of a BDA and plant DIAMETER at planting.

#Text=In addition, cohort 1 plants had variables for plant HEIGHT at planting and planting DEPTH (both of which were held constant in cohort 2) and for continuous DISTANCE from the stream (as described in Orr et al�2019).
#Text=Cohort 2 plants had variables for ELEVATION relative to groundwater and dichotomous DISTANCE (near/far) based on stream proximity.

#Text=Model selection was via stepwise comparison of Akaike information criterion (AIC) values to find the best_fit model using the Dredge function in the MuMIn package, and all non_relevant independent variables were dropped from the final model (Barton�2017).
#Text=All models were then evaluated using a goodness_of_fit test with the r.squared function (Nakagawa & Schielzeth�2013; Johnson�2014; Nakagawa et al�2017).

#Text=When model fit was poor as a GLMM, the model was rerun as a generalized linear model (GLM) without SITE as a random effect, and when model fit was improved, results were taken from the final GLM model after repeating the above selection process.
#Text=All results were back_transformed for ease of interpretation.
#Text=Survival was analyzed using a GLM and included survival as a binary variable using a logit link.

#Text=Survival GLMs included independent variables for BDA, DISTANCE (measured continuously for copse 1 and dichotomously (near/far) for copse 2), plant DIAMETER at planting (copses 1 and 2), plant HEIGHT at planting (copse 1), and planting DEPTH (copse 1).
#Text=DEPTH and HEIGHT were not included in the copse 2 model, as these parameters were kept constant at planting.
#Text=SITE was found not to be significant as a random effect in the preliminary GLMM analysis, which required dropping this parameter and adopting the above modeling approach.
#Text=Results.
#Text=Structure Integrity and Water Levels.

#Text=Over the period that the South Fork water gage was functioning, South Fork and mainstream Crooked flows were correlated over all months (0.83) and during high flow months from January to May (0.84).
#Text=Thus, flows in the mainstem Crooked were considered reliable surrogates of South Fork flows.
#Text=Peak mainstem Crooked flows explained over 80% of the variation in the number of BDAs that required annual maintenance (F=30.17;�df=1, 5;�r2adj=0.83;�p=0.003).

#Text=The relationship between peak flows and time spent on maintenance was not significant over the 6years that we conducted maintenance (F=3.2;�df=1, 4;�r2adj=0.0.31;�p=0.14), but it is likely that this was due to a lack of statistical power because when we added the year in which maintenance requirements (38hours) were estimated from observed damage to structures, the relationship was significant (F=12.55;�df=1, 6;�r2adj=0.67).
#Text=The number of structures requiring repair each year and the hours spent on repair are shown in Figure�3.

#Text=In the analysis of the number of structures needing maintenance, two points with slightly risky leverage values (0.27 and 0.24) had safe Cook's distance values (0.62 and 0.03); rerunning the test without the point with the higher Cook's�D�value did not substantially change the result (r2adj=0.87,�p=0.004).

#Text=In the analysis of the time spent on maintenance, two points with risky leverage values (0.26, 0.23) had safe Cook's�D�values (0.005, 0.48); rerunning the test without the point with the highest Cook's�D�value did not substantially change the result (r2adj=0.73,�p=0.019).
#Text=All other regression assumptions were met.

#Text=Readings of water level difference (�h) between stilling wells immediately upstream and downstream of intact BDAs ranged from 0.21 to 0.49m, with respective averages of 0.33+/_0.07, 0.37+/_0.06, and 0.35+/_0.06m for BDA 3 in 2021 and BDA 5 in 2020 and 2021 (Fig�4A__C).
#Text=Damage during high flows is correlated with losses in pond storage levels and drops in groundwater.

#Text=After damage from high spring flows in 2020 reduced water retention at BDA 5 to a �h�of just 0.05m between upstream and downstream wells, repairs on July 6 and 8 slowly returned �h�to less than 0.35m (Fig�4A).
#Text=Similarly, the 2m bank well had water levels similar to the downstream well before BDA repair, but after repair they rose to levels similar to or above the downstream well (Fig�4A).

#Text=Another line of evidence that BDAs elevated groundwater during our study period is that the upstream control bank well (2m) averaged 0.31+/_0.03m lower elevation than its adjacent in_stream control (Fig�4D), whereas 2m bank wells adjacent to BDAs 3 (2021) and 5 (2020, 2021) each averaged less than 0.10+/_0.05m lower elevation than adjacent wells upstream of BDAs.
#Text=Even wells 12m from the stream averaged within 0.26+/_0.03m of in_stream wells upstream of BDAs.
#Text=Control bank wells also showed smaller seasonal ranges (0.23 and 0.24m) compared to bank wells adjacent to BDAs (0.39+/_0.12m,�n=9).

#Text=Willow cuttings planted to 60cm depth would have remained submerged during the entire study period 2m from the stream, whereas willows would have been submerged inconsistently both over time and between sites 7 and 12m from the stream (Fig�4).
#Text=Figure 4\r\rRecorded water level elevations in wells surrounding BDA 5 in 2020 (A) and 2021 (B), BDA 3 in 2021 (C), and control wells in 2021 (D).
#Text=US stands for upstream.
#Text=DS stands for downstream.
#Text=The right�y_axis in (D) refers to the US wells.

#Text=Straight colored lines across the bottom in (A_C) signify periods when cuttings planted to a depth of 60cm would have been submerged for part of a day (dotted line) or all day (solid line) at each groundwater distance from the stream.
#Text=Colored numbers to the right of the colored lines show the full range of water table depths beneath the soil surface over the period shown.
#Text=Both in_stream and bank wells showed daily fluctuations in elevation and early morning peaks consistent with diurnal evapotranspiration (ET).
#Text=Groundwater well levels appeared tightly coupled to surface water levels 2 and 7m from the stream at BDA 5 and 2, 7, and 12m from the stream at BDA 3 (Fig�4A__C).

#Text=Groundwater levels in wells at 7m tracked close to or below 12m wells over most of the summer (Fig�4A__C), but at BDA 5, the 7m well rose in elevation from late July to mid_August in both years and thereafter tracked closer to the 2m well (Fig�4A�&�4B).
#Text=The sharp late_summer rise in water level at this 7m well is not explained by river levels nor by increases in hillslope inputs; the latter would have increased groundwater levels at 12m.
#Text=Thus, the late_season rise in 7m groundwater likely signaled a decrease in ET as seasonal levels of photosynthesis declined.
#Text=However, no similar change occurred in the 7m well at BDA 3, which is suggestive of localized site effects.
#Text=Despite elevating water levels, BDAs did not appear to buffer stream or groundwater levels against flow changes.
#Text=Instead, surface water fluctuations propagated rapidly along the river and into the groundwater wells, particularly at 2__7m distances.

#Text=This was most apparent in late May, late June, and late July of 2021, when fluctuations in water levels coming into the system at upstream control wells (Fig�4D) were similarly evident in wells around BDAs (Fig�4A__C).

#Text=Our observations in boreholes and streambanks suggest that alluvial stratigraphy in this area of the reach is loamy materials over gravel and cobble deposits, which are underlain by a thick, impermeable clay deposit.
#Text=The depth of gravel/cobble in the boreholes corresponds well with the elevation of the cobble_bottomed streambed.
#Text=We speculate that BDA_retained water transmits rapidly laterally from the stream through the gravels and loamy sediments of the floodplain, while the clay layer restricts vertical movement.
#Text=These mechanics would support the rapid groundwater well response we observed.
#Text=However, stream temperatures did not propagate rapidly into the riparian wells.
#Text=While in_stream wells frequently showed diel fluctuations of approximately 4 degrees C, daily oscillations of bank well temperatures only rarely exceeded 0.5 degrees C.
#Text=Sedimentation.
#Text=Sediment dynamics differed between the two entire topographic AOIs.
#Text=In AOI 1, deposition exceeded erosion in 2017, 1year after construction, to produce a net sediment gain of 38.1+/_31.0m3.
#Text=However, this pattern reversed in 2021, 4years after construction, when erosion exceeded deposition for a loss of 29+/_33.7m3�that came close to reversing the first_year gains.
#Text=AOI 2, in contrast, was net erosional in both the first year (32.3+/_29.9m3) and fourth year (76.9+/_41.6m3) after construction.
#Text=Figure�5�shows sedimentation responses in the three process zones around structures, which is where much of the change occurred.
#Text=Figure 5\r\rSchematic of topographic surveys and location of BDA process zones used to calculate sediment deposition and erosion in relation to BDA structures.
#Text=(A) High_resolution imagery of BDA 3 captured in the summer of 2017 just after high flows caused a breach and end cut of the structure on river right.
#Text=(B) Process zones in a digital elevation model (DEM) constructed from a 2017 topographic survey shortly after BDA 4 was installed 5m downstream from BDA 3 as a support structure.

#Text=(C & D) Net erosion (negative values) or deposition (positive values) of sediment in upstream, downstream, and end_cut process zones during the first year after structures were installed (light bars) and during subsequent years (dark bars).
#Text=Sedimentation values for Total AOI (as shown in Fig�1) are reported in the text.
#Text=Little erosion or deposition happened downstream of any BDAs (Fig�5C�&�5D).

#Text=Deposition was apparent upstream of the BDA in AOI 1, 1year following construction, as previously reported in Orr et al (2019); however, that sediment had evacuated by the fourth year after construction (Fig�5C).
#Text=End cuts at banks adjacent to BDA structures also accounted for a large amount of sediment erosion within both topographic AOIs (Fig�5C�&�5D).

#Text=Stream Temperature\rMaximum daily stream temperature from the uppermost to the lowermost logger in the reach (Fig�1) showed a general cooling trend moving downstream, with a mean difference of 0.48C (df=264,�t=24.4,�p<0.001; Fig�6A).
#Text=The sub_reach between RKM 1.5 and RKM 2.5 (Fig�1) exhibited cooling of mean maximum daily temperatures of 0.42C (df=264,�t=22.4,�p<0.001; Fig�6B).

#Text=Temperatures in the sub_reach between RKM 2.5 and BDA 3 (Fig�6C) and in paired sensors immediately above and below BDAs (Fig�6D) fell within the error margin of the logger accuracy range, indicating no local effect of BDAs on maximum daily water temperatures in this system.
#Text=Figure 6\r\rPoints show daily maximum stream temperatures at a downstream site (x_axis) paired with an upstream site (y_axis).
#Text=Gray lines on either side of the 1:1 black line show +/_0.2 degrees C sensor accuracy.
#Text=Points above the line indicate downstream cooling; points below indicate warming.
#Text=The reach encompassed by each site pairing is shown in the upper left of each panel.
#Text=Dates are 1 July 2020__9 October 2020 and 21 May 2021__31 October 2021.

#Text=Net cooling over the study reach (A) included reaches with cooling (B) and warming (C), while temperature differences between each logger pair upstream and downstream of a BDA were negligible (D).
#Text=Different symbols in (D) signify different BDAs.
#Text=The dashed line in panel (A) shows the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife critical temperature threshold for salmonids.
#Text=Riparian Vegetation\rIn growth models of cohort 2 plants, there was a significant amount of autocorrelation between the variables for SITE, DISTANCE, and ELEVATION.
#Text=Therefore, separate models were conducted for willows planted near and far from the stream, and ELEVATION was included as a fixed variable in a normal GLM.
#Text=Site was retained as a random effect in only one model (cohort 1, 2019), which was run as a GLMM; others were run as GLMs due to poor model fit when SITE was included.

#Text=The amount of variation in plant growth explained by the models, as measured by�r2�values, increased from our first to last measurements in all three planting treatments, including cohort 1 (2018n=192,�df=187,�r2=0.18; 2019n=136,�df=121,�r2=0.11; 2022n=43,�df=39,�r2=0.18), cohort 2 close to the stream (2019n=75,�df=74,�r2=0.24; 2022n=36,�df=35,�r2=0.30) and cohort 2 far from the stream (2019n=70,�df=69,�r2=0.23; 2022n=19,�df=18,�r2=0.65).

#Text=Plants near BDAs tended to grow more than plants far from BDAs in cohort 1 plants and cohort 2 plants close to the stream (Fig�7A�&�7B), The effects of BDAs, as indicated by GLM�values, increased over successive years of measurement in both cohort 1 plants (2018,�=1.32 (95% CI 1.11__1.59),�df=187,�p<0.01; 2019,�=2.49 (1.34__4.63),�df=121,�p<0.01; 2022,�=9.61 (2.46__198.0),�df=39,�p<0.001) and cohort 2 plants close to the stream (2019,�=1.41 (1.17__1.70),�df=74,�p<0.001; 2022,�=2.84 (1.55__5.64),�df=35,�p<0.001).
#Text=The BDA variable was not retained in cohort 2 plants far from the stream shortly after planting, but it was retained 3years after planting (=6.9 [2.88__58.7],�p<0.001).
#Text=However, its retention in the latter case was attributable to a single outlier (Fig�7C), which indicates that BDA effects on the growth of plants far from the stream were at best inconsistent.
#Text=Figure 7\r\rGrowth of living willow stems in surviving plants.
#Text=The�x_axis shows the number of years post_planting (0=4months post_planting).
#Text=The number above each box and whisker is the number of surviving plants.
#Text=Cohort 1 started with 94 cuttings in each treatment (+/_BDA).
#Text=Cohort 2 started with 40 cuttings in each treatment (+/_BDA and near/far from stream).
#Text=Year 0 post_planting results for cohort 1 are reported in Orr et al (2019).

#Text=A larger cutting DIAMETER was associated with better growth 4months after planting in both cohort 1 plants (Orr et al�2019) and cohort 2 plants close to the stream (=1.91 [1.43__2.49],�df=74,�p<0.001).
#Text=However, DIAMETER was not retained among these plants in any model in subsequent years.

#Text=In contrast, DIAMETER was retained in the model for cohort 2 plants far from the stream both 4months after planting (=2.04 [1.39__3.07],�df=69,�p<0.001) and 3years after planting (=5.29 [1.71__25.7],�df=18,�p<0.05), suggesting a larger role of cutting diameter in plant growth as water availability declines.

#Text=In cohort 1, planting DEPTH was associated positively with growth in all years measured, including after 4months (Orr et al�2019), after 3years (=1.03 [1.01__1.03],�df=121,�p<0.001), and after 4years (=1.04 [1.03__1.11],�df=39,�p<0.001).

#Text=In cohort 2, where planting depth was uniform but elevation above groundwater was not, the ELEVATION above grounwater was not retained in models 4months after planting, but by 3years after planting, it was inversely associated with growth, both near to the stream (=0.90 [0.78__0.97],�df=35,�p<0.05) and far from the stream (=0.84 [0.57__0.93],�df=18,�p<0.05).
#Text=Together, the effects of proximity to a BDA, planting DEPTH, and planting ELEVATION were consistent with the idea that deeper immersion promotes plant growth.
#Text=By the last year of observation, BDA��values were higher than values for DEPTH and ELEVATION, suggesting a possible longer term of BDAs, especially close to the stream.

#Text=In the survival analysis, cohort 1 willows far from a BDA had a 1_year survival rate about a quarter of those near BDAs (=0.23; CI=0.10__0.49;�p<0.0001); DEPTH and DIAMETER were retained in the year 1 model but were not significant.
#Text=By year 4, however, the only variable that remained in the survival model was DIAMETER, and its effect was not significant.
#Text=Among cohort 2 willows, DIAMETER was positively correlated with survival 4months after planting (=0.08; CI=0.01__0.74;�p<0.05), and DISTANCE was retained but not significant.
#Text=By year 3, only DISTANCE was associated with survival (=2.88; CI=1.45__5.84;�p<0.05); BDA was retained in the model but was not significant.
#Text=In summary, BDAs showed mixed short_term effects and no long_term effects on cutting survivorship.
#Text=The amount of variation in survival explained by the models shrank between early and later years, from 14 to 2% in cohort 1 and from 20 to 11% in cohort 2.
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Some, but not all, of the changes caused by BDAs at our study site in the short term persisted into the long term.
#Text=Trajectories in_stream and riparian responses were affected by BDA damage and maintenance, so we discuss that first.

#Text=Our finding that over 80% of the effort required to maintain BDAs was explained by peak stream flows suggests that a low stream gradient, which should reduce stream power, does not necessarily protect BDAs from high flows.

#Text=Rather than being a rare event, the damages that occurred after we first built our BDAs (Orr et al�2019) appear to be a regular characteristic of the system, which supports the hypothesis that peak flows can be a limiting factor in BDA_based restoration (Nash et al�2021).

#Text=BDAs frequently lose integrity or are destroyed, and, similarly to our BDAs, there was an inverse relationship between peak flows and the longevity of natural beaver dams on Bridge Creek (Demmer & Beschta�2008).
#Text=Peak flows above 175cfs have been shown to damage natural beaver dams in a system with approximately double the average base flows of the South Fork (Andersen & Shafroth�2010).
#Text=Our system exceeded 175cfs at least twice during our study and possibly in 2023 after the South Fork flow gage was decommissioned.

#Text=The amount of maintenance our structures required cannot easily be explained by design flaws because the same crew that oversaw construction in our study built structures in what is to date the most successful and widely cited study of BDAs (Bouwes et al�2016), and both studies were in the same Columbia River watershed.
#Text=The strong relationship we found between peak flows and BDA damage means that hydrographs should be considered carefully when weighing BDAs as a restoration intervention.
#Text=Beaver, though present, did not appear to mitigate BDA damage.

#Text=We found only small amounts of beaver_chewed sagebrush (Artemesia tridentata) inserted into our structures, possibly because upland woody species like sage are inaccessible and expose beavers to predation.

#Text=The difficulties of structure maintenance faced by beavers in locations lacking woody riparian vegetation constitute another planning consideration, although artificial structures are only inconsistently adopted by beavers even when vegetation is more available (Nash et al�2021; Sandbach et al�2024), and human maintenance is considered part of BDA_based restoration (Castro et al�2017).

#Text=The hours that we invested in repair may represent a low estimate if extrapolated to other projects, both because we contracted an experienced restoration crew with prior work in a nearby system, Bridge Creek (Bouwes et al�2016), and because our site had a rock quarry and an abundance of nearby vegetation for easy sourcing of dam materials.
#Text=The timing of BDA repair affected the trajectories of stream and riparian parameters, and to our knowledge, it constitutes an unexplored consideration in beaver_based restoration.
#Text=Flows were often high and water was cold in winter and early spring.
#Text=Under such circumstances, repair was unfeasible.
#Text=Because high flows carry higher sediment loads than low flows, structures were damaged and remained irreparable when sediment capture would otherwise have been most productive.

#Text=This was particularly evident at BDA 1, which trapped large volumes of sediment while remaining entirely intact during high flows in spring 2017 but lost most of that sediment after repeated structural damage in subsequent high flow years.

#Text=It was more feasible to maintain BDAs for plant growth than for sediment retention because riparian plants become water stressed only after flows have abated and in_stream repairs can be completed.

#Text=The rise in groundwater levels that occurred when we built our structures in 2016 (Orr et al�2019) remained stable throughout our study as long as BDAs were maintained, and were comparable to groundwater responses to BDAs at Bridge Creek (Bouwes et al�2016).

#Text=Differences between water elevations of in_stream stilling wells immediately upstream and downstream of BDAs 3 and 5 (0.21__0.49m) encompassed the 0.33m that beavers raised water levels after translocation and dam building in Washington (Dittbrenner et al�2022).

#Text=Consistent with how BDAs only consistently elevated groundwater above the bases of willows planted within 2m of the stream, BDAs were associated more strongly with willow growth near the stream than far from it.
#Text=It would be interesting to test for BDA effects further into the riparian zone using species such as alder or cottonwood that are adapted to drier habitats than Coyote willow (Hoag�2007).
#Text=In contrast to growth, the association between BDAs and willow survivorship seen after the first growing season in cohort 1 disappeared over the longer term and was never apparent in cohort 2.

#Text=Because the survival of riparian plantings can be improved by drilling deeper holes (Hall et al�2015), a mechanical auger to achieve greater depth of planting should be considered as either an alternative or an addition to BDAs to optimize plant establishment.
#Text=The significant effects of planting DEPTH and ELEVATION on plant growth further support the idea that deep planting improves growth.
#Text=Small_scale heterogeneity in water temperature has been documented around BDAs (Weber et al�2017) due to meter_scale vertical and lateral hyporheic exchange.
#Text=However, in_stream temperatures did not differ above and below our BDAs.

#Text=This was somewhat surprising because our BDAs raised riparian groundwater and our Hobo riparian well loggers registered temperatures 5__10 degrees C cooler in groundwater wells than in in_stream stilling wells.
#Text=Therefore, we might have expected hyporheic exchange and groundwater recharge to lower temperatures downstream of our BDAs.
#Text=Because our in_stream sensors were placed in the thalweg to assess larger_scale changes and prevent exposure during low flows, we cannot rule out localized effects nearer the bank.

#Text=Associations between structures and stream temperature vary among studies of both BDAs (Weber et al�2017; Munir & Westbrook�2021b) and natural beaver dams (Dittbrenner et al�2022), and the temperature findings we report here apply only to the months under study.

#Text=In the same way that we saw no evidence of hyporheic riparian recharge lowering in_stream temperatures, water levels rapidly propagating between surface water and bank groundwater sensors did not affect groundwater temperatures.

#Text=Though tangential to the goals of this study, the decoupling of thermal measurements from water level measurements in our wells suggests complex structure_scale stream_groundwater interactions that may merit future study.

#Text=Temperatures in our groundwater wells could have been buffered by thermal stratification within a well, colder riparian sediments, down_vally flow, or colder hillslope flows backed up around wells due to diminished lateral head gradients at the BDAs.

#Text=The number of structures permitted to be built in BDA projects can be limited by land agencies (eg Charnley�2018), landowner preferences (Pilliod et al�2018), and project funding (Castro et al�2017).
#Text=The number of structures we tested here was limited by all three.
#Text=Although on the low end, our sample size of structures is not inconsistent with other studies.
#Text=We spaced our structures to produce experimental replication.
#Text=In contrast, beavers often build dams closely together in complexes.

#Text=Castro et al (2017) and Wheaton et al (2019) recommend building BDAs in complexes to enhance structure durability, although fewer than half of the published BDA projects we reviewed here built complexes.

#Text=Our findings regarding durability and maintenance might have differed had our BDAs been built in complexes, but doing so would have reduced or eliminated experimental replication of willow copses.
#Text=The PALs that we built below BDAs 1, 2, and 5 in 2020 can be considered a component of complexes (Wheaton et al�2019, Chapter 4) and were installed as additional structural support.
#Text=Nevertheless, the PALs did not prevent the destruction of our BDAs during the first high flows after their installation.

#Text=The PALs might have offered some protection to BDAs during low flows, given that the only years that no maintenance was required were the two low flow years after PALs were built; however, maintenance in low flow years was also low before PALs were present.
#Text=Between our study and those we review here, research has documented a mix of successful and unsuccessful restoration outcomes associated with BDAs.
#Text=In that regard, our study is no exception, although ours is the first we are aware of that has documented the reversal of restoration trajectories over time.
#Text=In addition, ours is the first we know of that quantifies the maintenance effort of BDAs in response to peak flows.

#Text=We emphasize that effort spent on structure maintenance can help to support some restoration outcomes, like raising groundwater during peak growth periods of riparian vegetation, but maintenance can become intensive and may be impossible during periods of peak sediment transport.

#Text=Our findings suggest that BDA_based restoration plans should carefully define desired future conditions and project for future costs of structure maintenance and the information that can be acquired by long_term monitoring.

#Text=Acknowledgments\rThis research was funded by a 2020 grant (# 220_4032_17369) from the Oregon Watershed Enhancement Board, a 2016 Watershed Restoration grant from the Bella Vista Foundation, and a 2020 OSU_Cascades Layman Fellowship to S.B.
